review: A decent but irregular effort that feels too long for the kind of story that it wants to tell and not really well polished as a whole, while its unusual aspect ratio of 1:1 may be interesting, especially as a basis for the most beautiful scene of the film, but also starts to bother after some time.

Xavier Dolan likes to do the epics so I am not sure if I saw the pure director's cut but this is nonetheless a good descent into the world of the working class in Montreal with a serious treatment of mental illness and how one single mother dealt with her child's ailment. Once again a masterpiece.

Canada's entry for Best Foreign Language Film at the 87th Academy Awards, "Mommy" is Xavier Dolan's best work to date. It's a powerfully moving film with smothering performances and Dolan's trademark style. It will punch you in the gut, seemingly for the fun of it, then show you the valid intention of that punch that will leave you in somber gratitude. Good luck at this year's Oscars, "Mommy." I have very high hopes for you.

While I can't say I "enjoyed" the movie, I loved the filmmaking talent present from Xavier Dolan (loved both widescreen sequences and the ending), I'm looking forward to watching his career and checking out his past films. A promising talent.

Many describe this Canadian film as an emotional horror show, and make no mistake, Mommy will leave you shaken. Writer-director Xavier Dolan debuted six years ago with I Killed My Mother and Oedipal issues are still on the menu in Mommy, in which a 15-year-old, omnisexual, possible bi-polar boy named Steve (Antoine Olivier Pilon) is more than his widowed mother, Diana 'Die' Despres (Anne Dorval) can handle.A new law taking effect in Quebec will allow for a parent to institutionalize a child without a court procedure, which gets Die to thinking. She's only about 50, and her tight pants and tall heels suggest she's not ready for retiring from life anytime soon. The trouble is that blond, blue-eyed Steve is very charming when not setting things on fire or threatening people with violence. Die seeks help from her neighbor (Suzanne Clement) a delicate looking teacher who only thinks she can contain Steve.One thing about Mommy: Even when Dolan hits you over the head with his themes, he puts on a show that burns in the memory with images that are unforgettable. Pilon is firing on all cylinders, but it's the tour de force from Dorval that transcends language and cultural barriers. Hers is a performance that dares you not to watch.

Wunderkind Dolan (25 years old & this is his fifth movie) builds wave after wave of intensity in this shattering character study of damaged families trying their best to fit into a society which just seems impossible to navigate. Anne Dorval is amazing as the fierce and wacky Mommy who improvises her parenting and providing skills as a recent widow without much going for her but looks and love. Pilon is amazing as the explosive adolescent Steve, a singular creation for such a young actor. Dolan's sense of pacing, framing, scoring and use of music, and his work with actors is pretty remarkable. This is a career to watch.

The story revolves around a single mother's attempt to raise her ADHD teenage son. Sometimes you need to appreciate the little things in life because what runs in Diane's mind is hope , a dream she wants so bad, the hope of a normal life.
La verdad no me gust� el final del protagonista c: pero todo todo lo dem�s s�, as� que puedo soportarlo.
An engrossing drama about loss and motherhood that is skillfully directed and acted. One of Xavier Dolan's best films to date. A moving, powerful film that should't be missed.

While it's offbeat style and duration will put some people off - Mommy is an undeniably moving drama that is carried by Xavier Dolan's daring direction, unforgettable performances from it's 3 leads and an unflinchingly honest exploration of ADHD.
8,3 Antoine Olivier Pilon deserves something like an oscar for his performance

Beautiful, haunting, funny, brutal and heartbreaking all at once. Mommy is an example of a near perfect drama film, with deft direction from Xavier Dolan, raw performances from it's leads, and a poignant story that's both original and honest

I wonder how he could describe mom's view in this reality though he's not a parent. The reality about mom is more with , but I love richness in this movie, which Xavie Dolan is good for. All the movie is full with Steve's rich emotions, mom's love and worries.

A true modern masterpiece, as well as Xavier Dolan's crowning achievement as a writer director. There is not one flaw to be found within Mommy. Films just don't get better than this. It's without question one of my all-time favorite films, a legit instant classic of next-level filmmaking. The central performances are astounding. I don't know if Dolan will ever top this one, but I won't be surprised if he does.

This film is just Xavier Dolan at its best. I don't even know where to start since this movie has a lot to be commented about. Firstly, I decided to watch the movie, after I almost gave up because I thought the movie file or my player software had a problem because the screen appeared squeezed and short-sized and I didn't know what was going on, then I kept watching it and I realized it was made on purpose by this fantastic young director, the screen wideness got wider or smaller trough the movie regarding the mood, the feelings or the situations in the plot. It was the first time I saw such approach in films, to be honest. Then, there is the actors performance, which is brilliant trough the whole movie, mainly the main actress' performance, but the performance of the main male actor is a standout to point too. This plot addresses some interesting points, such as a dysfunctional mom-son relationship ala Nornam Bates and his mother, a maladaptive behavior of a person with ADHD and its percussions to the people around him, simple themes as love, friendship. The whole movie is just filled with emotions. Not to mention the soundtrack of this film, it is indeed proper for the scenes, well chosen and great. I certainly hope to see more of these cinema art pieces from this director.

Everything, from the powerhouse acting and memorable soundtrack to the color resolution and captivating cinematography, Mommy delivers. It's a hauntingly hypnotic picture that refuses to lose energy, all-the-while inviting the audience inside the world of a troubled teen, his widowed mother, and a helpful neighbor. Yay for catharsis!

Xavier Dolan, in his fifth feature, delivers an incredible film; with heartfelt performances from Anne Dorval and Antoine-Oliver Pilon, an unusual 1:1 aspect ratio and an excellent soundtrack, 'Mommy' is a must-see movie and another triumph into Dolan's filmography.
One of the best foreign films of the year!

*SPOILER FILLED REVIEW - ONLY READ THIS REVIEW WHEN YOU HAVE FINISHED THIS FILM*It is a jarring movie to watch. I find it beautiful yet traumatising to watch as it is a rather unconventional movie, mainly because of the unusual relationship between Die and Steve and the unconventional screen size (1:1), which adds a sense of perversion as we watch these characters unfold in our eyes and the feeling of claustrophobia because of the dimensions and the close shots. As for this movie, I thought this movie was well-acted and shot. I find Die and Steve's relationship as a mother and son was a little frightening and very complex. Steve's actor really did shine through with this film and the struggle was convincing and did find this child to be scary enough to be close to. I thought Kyla's actress was great and was a joy to watch her interact with Steve as she helps the struggling family despite having problems of her own and nearly almost neglecting her own family. This movie was just full of compassion and kindness added with the chaos of Steve's ADHD, a little uncomfortable to watch but an eye opener to the potential and talent that the actors and Dolan have.

What a strong and intense movie!! The main characters are such a mess that the only thing they can do is hold on to each other and the actors just carry this feeling extremely well. All in all this film turns up to be an astonishing piece of drama...

The story revolves around a single mother's attempt to raise her ADHD teenage son. Sometimes you need to appreciate the little things in life because what runs in Diane's mind is hope , a dream she wants so bad, the hope of a normal life.

Seen it. Don't know what to say yet.

Small in scale, but ferocious in feeling, "Mommy" is another astonishing feature from writer-director Xavier Dolan. A fitting companion piece to his debut "J'ai tu� ma mere," Dolan continues his exploration of combustible mother-son relationships. While Dolan mainly holds an attitude of angst toward the maternal figure in "J'ai tu� ma mere," he views the mother with a far more compassionate gaze in "Mommy." The eponymous matriarch is Diane 'Die' Depr�s (Anne Dorval), a widow struggling to look after her son Steve (Antoine-Olivier Pilon), who suffers from ADHD and other undiagnosed mood disorders. While Die looks for work, Steve is home-schooled by their reticent neighbour Kyla (Suzanne Cl�ment). The three central performers are outstanding. In Dorval and Cl�ment, Dolan has secured himself two complex and fascinating female leads. Both are expressive actresses who can communicate tremendous emotion and subtext even in the absence of dialogue. Newcomer Pilon offers contrast to their subtlety with his exuberant yet sincere performance. Steve is a heartbreaking character, who possesses this pure and unconditional love, but is often unable to express it appropriately. His frustration quickly gets distorted and fuelled into fits of rage and aggression. Dolan writes from a personal place, which often makes his work painfully honest and real. He makes these private, intimate moments not only cinematically compelling, but also emotionally resonant and relatable. There's a hand-sewn originality to Dolan's work that captivates and sets him apart as an artist.

This is a difficult film to describe. It's about a mother who is given custody of her (previously incarcerated) out of control and slightly psychopathic son and the journey they go on in an attempt to lead a normal life together. Both leads are captivating and you find yourself really hoping that things are going to turn out well. There is a stand out, dream / wish fulfilment sequence whether the mother finds herself imagining one possible future and the ending was unexpected, worth watching for something different from the norm.
the aspect ratio thing was genius
Esta peli es un drama,que en lo personal,no me termino de convencer. 5/10
Gorgeously shot, perfectly acted and with and amazingly effective and mind blowing soundtrack, Mommy is one of Dolans best films to date and another magnificent staple of modern foreign dramas.
Excellent first ten minutes and then the Xavier Dolan ego kicks in yet again. Awful.
The two actresses are incredible!

A wonderful Canadian movie with amazing performances from Anne Dorval and Antoine Pilon and a really excellent screenplay. Though I had to pause many times just to take a break from reading the subtitles, it is a really riveting family drama full of great heavy dramatic material but still some really joyful moments including many well crafted montages. It has a weird style of cinematography being shot in a very tight frame like you are looking through a crack of a door the whole time but when it does extend into full screen, it's like you can feel the tension break in the movie. Xavier Dolan is a very interesting director that I want to look into more of his work and excited for his future work. It also has a great soundtrack including a beautiful finale involving one of my favorite songs by Lana Del Rey

The third feature in my 'Dolanathon' catch-up manoeuvre and thus far the best thing Dolan has served up. Obvious (and unnecessary) style tricks aside.Sure, subtlety still isn't his thing and he needs to steer cleer from too many pop song intermezzos. But as far as character and theme goes, his severe mommy issues have finally paid off.Recommended.

Mommy is gripping, ferocious filmmaking. It's utterly sad and hard to watch, but the acting is EXCELLENT and the theme of motherhood phenomenal. The writer/director of the film, Xavier Dolan, just turned 26 this year. 26!!! And now he has the rest of his life to make even better movies. How exciting!
For planned parenthood haters and film lovers alike. How do you turn a difficult subject into an inventive, entertaining, moving and constructive film? This is how.

Perhaps Xavier Dolan's best film yet, and his most difficult to watch. Every moment is full of tension because of the 15-year-old Steve (played with charm to spare by Antoine-Olivier Pilon) who has ADHD and perhaps other behavioral issues. It is never certain when he is going to lash out in violence or some other inappropriate action. HIs mom "Die" (the always fantastic Anne Dorval) is forced to take him back in after he is kicked out of a youth detention center after he causes a fire that badly burns another child. Adding to the stress, she loses her job and her car is totaled. She puts on a brave and hopeful and vivacious face, but she might have some behavioral issues at well, though she is much more high functioning. After Steve nearly strangles her and she escapes to hide in a closet, the woman from across the street, Kyla (the also always fantastic Suzanne Cl�ment), intervenes and seems to have a way with him that calms him down. She soon becomes a part of their routine, providing home-schooling for Steve and another adult to engage with for Die. With Steve, though, his next behavioral outburst might be just a scene away.Dolan films the movie in a claustrophobic square frame, with huge black bars on the sides on a widescreen TV. Once in a great while, when there seems to be hope that things are turning around for the better, the frame suddenly widens to fill the full rectangle. When it tightens again...By the end of the film, it was unclear to me what other options were available for this woman and her son. It was also unclear to me exactly what was going on with Kyla, a woman of quirks that suggest a difficult recent occurrence that is never explicitly stated. Despite the difficult material and the horrifying situation, the movie is full of warmth and humor and sharp dialogue. Dolan dials back his signature artistic flourishes, but only a little, and it is always wonderful to see what he can do with his camera, filters, shots, and editing. After four of his five movies to date as writer/director/editor and sometimes actor (he does not appear in this film) he has become one of my most favorite artists. I'm looking forward to watching Tom at the Farm which comes out in the United States soon, and he is busy working on his next films, including It's Only the End of the World and his English-language debut as director, The Death and Life of John F. Donovan.

While I can't say I "enjoyed" the movie, I loved the filmmaking talent present from Xavier Dolan (loved both widescreen sequences and the ending), I'm looking forward to watching his career and checking out his past films. A promising talent.
I was surprised to find this movie, and pleased with myself for choosing to see it. I REALLY liked it.

How could I stay motionless and so speechless face with this DIAMOND !!! Sur, I just can sit on my chair, look at and just say "It's nice yep"... this is like a mirror on me and my past , just like all Dolan Movie's
Wonderwall.and Born To Die.
Emotionally enveloping

Last September, I had the amazing opportunity to volunteer at the Toronto International Film Festival, or better known as, TIFF. With this amazing opportunity also came amazing perks such as free movie vouchers for each shift we completed. I knew going into this festival that Mommy was my number one choice on my list of movies I needed to see before the festival ended. I have seen 3 of the 4 other films by director Xavier Dolan and he has since become my favourite director, so seeing this film was a must.Before I get into the review, I have a bit of a story to tell. Now, you may think that as a volunteer you had a 100% chance of seeing the films you wanted. That is definitely not the case. You have to remember TIFF is one of the only film festivals that is also open to the public. Almost as soon as the tickets went on sale, Mommy was sold out. If you get to the box office as soon as it opens on the day the film is being screened there may be a chance that tickets are still on sale. Of course, for Mommy they were completely sold out. One of the perks of TIFF is that they have last minute entry on a RUSH line basis which means in the off chance there are any seats left they give them out to whoever is at the front of the RUSH line. The movie wasn't being shown until 12:00 in the afternoon and I got in line at 7:30 AM, because that is how badly I wanted to see this movie, and of course I was first in line. At around 9:00 AM a man came up to the front of the line and asked if by any chance anyone was here in line to see Mommy. I raised my hand and said that I was thinking that he was just checking to see if people had already started lining up for the film but, to my very lucky surprise he had an extra ticket and gave it to me free of charge. I was of course ecstatic! Now let's get on to that review. Out of all the films I have seen by Xavier Dolan, his first film (I Killed My Mother) has always been my favourite...until now. This film was emotional and heartbreaking and just such a pleasure to watch. The acting was incredible by all three leads. Anne Dorval and Suzanne Cl�ment have been in a few of Dolan's other films and were miraculous in each role so it didn't surprise me when they were just as amazing in Mommy. The real surprise came from Antoine-Olivier Pilon whom I have never seen in any film before. I wasn't sure what to expect, but he was perfect for this role.The special thing about this movie is the way that it is shot, in a perfect square. I was lucky enough to attend a Q&A with Xavier Dolan after the film had finished playing and someone in the crowd asked him what the hardest part about making this film was and his answer was the way it was shot and trying to fit everyone into the frame. I can honestly say that I did not see any evidence of that struggle. Everything looked perfectly framed to me which just proves how much time and effort Dolan spends on making things perfect.The soundtrack was what I was most worried about. I saw a trailer for the movie before TIFF started and it used very commercialized, popular songs that have been on the top charts on the radio recently. In previous films, Dolan was more artistic with his music choices so going into this film I was a little worried about what the music choices might be. Although they were common songs that majority of people have heard, the way they were used and what they meant made up for any doubt I had. The songs worked perfectly, and in some strange case, made me feel new emotions while listening to them which was also another topic that Dolan addressed during the Q&A.I was also lucky enough to meet Xavier after the Q&A session and he was beyond kind and spoke to everyone that stayed behind to meet him. He answered more questions, signed autographs and took photos with all of us even after people told him he had to leave.All in all, I would have been happy just to attend this one film and have all the experiences that I did, but TIFF is a 10 day long festival and I was able to see two other films in between volunteer shifts, so keep an eye out for those reviews coming soon.I highly recommend checking out all of Xavier Dolan's films, but especially Mommy if you ever have the pleasure of getting your hands on this film in the near future!

This was Xavier Dolans best film to date. A widowed mum has to cope with her teenage son with ADHT. She befriends her neighbour Kyla and all 3 put in spotless performances. This film was hard too watch in places but it left me speechless. Astounding from start to finish.
display of struggle and affection, the tease of redemption is heart breaking. Great performance all round.

An unusual take on life and the difficulties of parenting that was at times hard to watch. Still the mum and son have their own unique and weird relationship, full of cursing and a lot of problems. The acting was brilliant and a bit depressing in a way but expertly done.

What is normal, and what will help you feel it? Family tragedies, mental health issues, and everyday life combine in this highly intense film about coping with loss and finding yourself amidst the grief. This film pops with great performances and creative film-making.

Watching "Mommy" unfold is a mixture of annoyance, amazement and ultimately astonishing. Xavier Dolan finally finds his grounding in deceptively "simple" story of mother trying to come to terms with her son's mental challenges. Dolan's cinematographer, Andr� Turpin, applies the director's idea of trying to find a visual way to capture the limited and isolated reality that traps both mother and child. It is particularly challenging at first. In fact, if the cinema had not warned the Canadian audience, I think we all would have thought there was some sort of projection problem. The idea is fantastic and the eyes quickly adjust. It is a transportive device. Featuring three amazing performances -- Anne Dorval is particularly riveting. This movie is grounded in a harsh and often brutal reality -- and yet the actors bring out moments of true bliss that make it bearable. An unforgettable cinematic experience. Xavier Dolan has been making interesting films for some time, but he truly makes his mark with this devastating and tragically beautiful movie. It is exciting to write that he has made a film that is a must see.
A powerfully moving film with gripping performances and one hell of visual storytelling.

You know what sucks? I already did my top movies of 2014 list, now if I only watched this movie before making the list this would have made the list easily. Well I got something to learn next time.The story is about a single mom's drama about raising her son, who's behavior deteriorates into violence, due to a mild mental illness.I first took interest in the film Mommy just because of the hype and the positive praise it got from the 2014 Cannes Film Festival and the amount of awards it won from the Jutra Awards and Canadian Screen Awards for best Foreign Language film, but not a Academy Award for Foreign Film at the Oscars. Since I am watching more Foreign Language films and searching the ones that got high ratings or just the ones that may interest me, because I'm taking a break from some movies today as they normally not very good or just too Hollywood for me, I mean movies today are getting pretty stale and cliche as nothing feels originally anymore. When Hollywood tries to make a original movie that's down to earth it's laughable. These something about Foreign Language films that always feel real and sometimes so tight with it's story and ending that most movie studios will shy away from and I love it. So I checked out the 2014 Award Wining Mommy and it was absolutely brilliant, I mean how could I even dear overlook this I mean this is a great movie right here and true film making at it's best.Not only did the Oscar screw up for not awarding this for Best Foreign Language film, they also didn't nominate Anne Dorval for Best Actress, because she did one of the best, the most heart felt and the most real piece of performance I've seen in 2014. I felt her struggle and the mix relationship between her and the missed behaved son. There was many scenes in the movie were the son and her have this argument over each over and it never felt like I was just watching actors reading out the script and pretending that they related, no they back and forward arguments always felt real and I bough it. Oh and I found out most of the awards that this movie won are not just for the Foreign Language Award but most of the awards went to her and she deserves it and a Oscar too for god shake. At the Cannes Film Festival Julianne Moore won for Best Actress for Maps to the Stars and I haven't seen Maps to the Stars yet so I can't really judge on her performance in that movie since I haven't seen it, but Anne Dorval was nominated in that category so it was disappointing that she didn't take the award, but I have seen Still Alice and she won a Oscar for that role, but Anne Dorval should have took that Oscar home as she did a much better than Moore as I connected to Anne Dorval more and how her performance made me feel different emotions that I never felt before while watching the movie.Antoine-Olivier Pilon is a unknown star to me as I haven't seen him in any other movies before so this is basically the first ever performance I get to see him in and man god can this kid act, I mean he was so good in the movie. Just like I said about Anne Dorval and that is all the time it never felt like acting to me, it felt real. Antoine plays the misbehaved son perfectly that he actually catches the trouble child very well since I have seen young people like him in real life and how they act is just like him. I also love how they never force the message of "He's got a mental illness oh feel sorry for him". The movie never puts that in your face like most movies do when they try to be realistic or make you feel something for the character. He's performance showed both angry, goofy, troubled and damaged but all that is in he's performance and it never feels force and that was so well done that movie didn't slip into that cliche that happens in most movies and that's due to Antoine-Olivier Pilon excellent performance.The director of the movie Xavier Dolan which I haven't really seen any of his last work so this is my first movie directed by him and a great start. This is film making at it's best, I mean the cinematography is beautiful, the tone of the movie can switch to serious drama but quickly change to happy and many other tones and it didn't ruin the movie like most do. Xavier Dolan did both a excellent job on directing the movie and making this as down to earth as possible showing characters and they problems that most people can relate to. Awesome work Xavier Dolan.For problems with the movie I haven't really got any to be honest, but I'm not going to give this the perfect rating as I think this isn't on the level of 5/5 rating it can ever get it, but the rating I'm giving it is really outstanding and it's the highest rating I give this week.Overall I say that Mommy is worth checking it if you haven't seen it yet. It's worth your time and don't do the same mistake as I did and not watch this fantastic movie.

Few movies have ever made me felt quite so alive, so invigorated, so uplifted and so compassionate for the characters as Xavier Dolan's affectingly human masterpiece Mommy. I'll never forget Steve, or Diane, or Kyla, nor will I ever stop caring about their lives and that speaks volumes about the emotional power and intensity on show here.
So many different emotions. Powerful work which suits well with 1:1 ratio.

With well developed but annoying and despicable characters, awful and frustrating aspect ratio, extremely bloated running time and bad approach with too much cursing, yelling and some sick scenes, Mommy is a huge disappointment and although it is very well directed and acted with fantastic performances, it is also a bit unbelievable at times, annoying for the most of its long running time and above all a very unpleasant watch.

Wonderful movie, definitely one of the few films that have touched my heart and mind of a sudden. The truth is the first time I heard it did not feel very attracted and I considered not to view this movie on cinema but I'm totally regret. I found an excellent, true masterpiece with an exquisite visual style, very deep and powerful, Xavier Dolan shows his sweet and sensitive colorful style. In every scene showing each sequence and each plane managed an impressive quality. A soundtrack that is exhilarating which transports you and makes you reflect. A true masterpiece, I loved it so much... very good job ... 5/5

My first Xavier Dolan flick. I've heard lots of things from his films, being a young new-shot and everything."Mommy" turned out to be a very powerful film. It's dealing with issues relevant as ever, where a troubled child are being handled by his mother as she tries her best. Ordinary people. Troubled kid. Troubled mother. Troubled neighbours.It's superbly acted. The three leads are magnificent, but Antoine-Olivier Pilon as the boy and Anne Dorval as the mother really impress. If Pilon does not have some sort of ADHD-dignose he better get himself checked. Magnificent!This is very affecting stuff and the way it is presented is flawless. The narrow screen makes put's you more directly into the situations. You are in the house with the struggling family. It's a bit demanding, but very rewarding. Some genious editing are topping the appearance of the film - a very clever and original touch.It's not the easiest of films to watch. It's rugged, it's heartbreaking, it's very real. It got an incredible character build-up - one of the very finest I have seen. It's intelligent and a bit of fresh air I must say. The music also blend so nicely with the dull colors, the brilliant cinematography, and there are superb dialogue here. Many great scenes, I can easily count 10 big scenes for me here.This film will stay with me for a while. I'm looking forward to it. I got to see more of Dolan's work that's for sure.9 out of 10 squares.

One of the most jaw-dropping movies in recent years, this blackly comical drama is the most audacious work yet from Canadian filmmaker Xavier Dolan. As challenging as it is rewarding, Mommy finds writer-director Xavier Dolan taking another impressive step forward. Dolan is a director who thinks hard about the possibilities of cinema and explores them with verve and ingenuity, but it is in his latest film that everything has come together. There are ups and downs and soapish highs and lows, but what stops this from ever becoming a telenovela is the riveting wonder of the performances and the sheer brio of the filmmaking. Mommy is first and foremost a mother-and-son story, but it's also a surprisingly delicate exploration of lonely lives, and the temporary islands of companionship that make them bearable. It's uncanny how much Dolan's style and overall solipsism have evolved in five years' time, resulting in a funny, heartbreaking and, above all, original work - right down to its unusual 1:1 aspect ratio - that feels derivative of no one, not even himself. Anne Dorval, Antoine Olivier Pilon and Suzanne Cl�ment give scary-good performances.This is easily Dolan's best film, and it's exciting to think how many times we might have to revise that statement over the years to come. Mommy is going to linger. The love, the laughter, the anger and the sorrow--it sticks. This film earned a place in the top three of my favourite films of all time.VERDICT: "Instant Classic" - [Positively Acclaimed Reaction] Usually I give this rating to a movie that I believe is absolutely outstanding and has little to no flaws in it. Audiences, who haven't seen this film, must see it right now! (Films that are rated 4.5 or 5 stars)
Ugh this movie is so good

This is bravura filmmaking by any standard. Dolan employs all the elements of film - sound, lighting, music and even the size and shape of his framing - to great effect. That not all of it works is immaterial, because the skill and intention is evident. There are sequences here, most notably the kitchen dance, pre-climax future fantasy and final shots, that are as superb as any I've seen. It's often an unpleasant film to watch, but each actor does strong work that carries us through - especially Clement, who, in the tricky role of the outsider drawn in, lays bare an entire life in her face.

An intense and heartbreaking story between a struggling mother and her problematic teenage son. Beautifully filmed and the storytelling was emotionally stunning. Tough to watch, but worth your while. A must see!

Mommy was breathtakingly awesome.Clearly Xavier Dolan's best work so far,Mommy deserves all the atention it gets.The acting is spectacular,actually all actors give their souls into their roles.But the direction is at its best!Everything about this story is painful,feels real and has soul.Incredible!
Anne Dorval was amazing in this!

Xavier Dolan is this generations Orson Welles at age 25 and five films to his resume he is ferocious groundbreaking and born with a gift his films gets better and better and Cannes Jury prize Winning film "Mommy" is by far his best work a powerful film about a Mothers love for her son its messy at times violent melodramatic but it works and it was necessary for this film. The entire cast was outstanding.
Good, but overlong. I liked the 1:1 aspect ratio.
Pretty disturbing, but good. Won Jury Prize at Cannes.
Mother's love and compassion is never ending, whatever you are. This film is successful translating that.
Con una propuesta visual s�lida y eficiente, una trama sorpresiva y actuaciones fabulosas, este es uno de los mejores films del a�o.
Abusively real about love and compassion.

very good directing , the cast was good music and songs were great , using 1:1 aspect ratio worked aswell helped to focus on characters tho if going wide screen 1st time was nice trick , 2nd time it was a letdown . main problem of the movie was the script , there was no 1 strong dialoge or monologe from characters , movie felt too long for that script and it made some plot holes . the best parts in the movie were the scenes with no talking . and i did not get why soo many people find this movie funny , some idiot talking shit to his mom is funny ? not for me . and Steve was very far from Gump or rain man in terms of creating sympathy to care for him .

Dolan trae el cometido del cine a la cara del espectador de una manera sutilmente, en una pel�cula que logra establecerse en la intimidad pero tambi�n en lo inc�modo de lidiar con las situaciones que la vida ofrece y que comunmente son ignoradas tal y como el caso del tri�ngulo afectivo entre Diane, Steve y Kyla. Aparte de contar con un gui�n familiar que ya lo caracteriza (los numerables defectos en el ser humano, pero especialmente en la relaci�n madre e hijo), Xavier Dolan despliega un juego visual que nos hace sentir en carne propia la b�squeda de la libertad, el enfrentamiento ante nosotros mismos y la m�s importante: la uni�n inquebrantable que se forja cuando una persona logra entregarse y mejorar hacia con el/la que tiene al lado. Un nudo en la garganta es el efecto final que "Mommy" logra establecer en el espectador, invitandolo a cuestionarse acerca de la verdadera importancia de quienes nos rodean.

I really am not fond of Xavier Dolan, but damn if he didn't (mostly) win me over with this one. Not completely. I rather intensely dislike his characters, which has always been my main problem with his films, and it's fairly clear that he likes his characters a lot. It usually stops me from getting swept up by his films ... here I ended up being along for the ride. The majority of this film is framed at a peculiar 1:1 ratio, which seems like a gimmick until the film opens up to 1.85:1 for a key sequence. That sequence alone was enough to really win me over.

Very powerful drama that deals with difficulties of being a single mother and a mentally unstable boy and the tough and uneasy decisions and choices she has through go through. Anne Dorval gives a powerhouse performance and you feel all her pain, love and hope. In a just world she would had been nominated for an Oscar. My favorite foreign language film of 2014

What to say about this film? Difficult to digest, overwhelming , exhausting , heavy, both that adorable, funny and filled with love. Director Xavier Dolan succeeds to intertwine feelings and emotions while bringing an excellent direction and good performances by all of its cast.
beautiful movie. you can call it a love story.
Xavier Dolan em escala ascendente!

In some respects an undeniably old fashioned melodrama (albeit with far worse language if you understand French), yet punches well above its weight due to the power of the three central performances. Its searing portrayal of the damage the parent-child bond can do reminds us that dramatic realism can, in its own way, be far more terrifying than any horror movie.

Great acting performances, powerful shots, a well-chosen soundtrack and the skills of Xavier Dolan lead to a movie that doesn't just entertain and move you for one night, but stimulates for a long time. Anne Dorval, Suzanne Cl�ment and Antoine Pilon form an acting triplet which is as convincing and impressing as it gets. A must-see.
'Mommy' manages to do what an important piece of art does: communicate authentic feelings....
The most self indulgent Instagram feed on ADHD I have ever seen. Thanks again, Xavier Dolan. Still love you!
Mommy is a masterpiece of a film. It has brilliant acting, one of the most beautiful cinematographies youll find this year, brilliant directing, and a great emotional story at its core.

A roller coaster of emotions, this is a great book end to boyhood from another parallel universe. I can not believe the director is a 25 year old Quebecois. The energy and life pulsating from this movie is unbelievable. The kitchen dance scene is simple yet so emotionally poignant. Wow wow wow.

Xavier Dolan's favorite mother-son's complicated love/hate exploration- with his artistic (especially for visual- by majorly using an 1:1 aspect ratio this time) signature on it.The big round of applause reception means this is his most successful, & probably the maturest work up-to-date, not my personal preference though.Stunning performance by the 3 main cast, by the way.
Muy buena, otra gran pel�cula de Xavier Dolan

Effing weird but good Canadian indie film. Depressing and hard to watch but also rewarding and heartfelt. Bit too long and somewhat pretentious, plus a distracting aspect ratio (but that pays off later and you learn was chosen for a reason). Pretty intense, and not easily forgotten.

As of right now, Xavier Dolan has made two masterworks out of his five films so far: Laurence Anyways and Mommy. Ferocious, funny, over-indulgent, messy, and claustrophobic, Mommy soars thanks to Dolan's technical prowess and the monumental performances from the three leads. As much as the film talked about hope and redemption, I'm not quite sure anyone achieved any by the end. While most would see this film as three people coming together to form an odd family unit, I'd say it's more about three people whom society has deemed unusual and wants nothing to do with. Die is unorthodox and a little shameless, Steve is fiery and problematic but mostly misunderstood, and Kyla can't seem to find the right words while no one seems willing to want to help or understand her. A film just as much about emotions brought to the surface as it is about the things that go unsaid. The film is also incredibly gorgeous and the unusually aspect ratio plays as a gimmick at first but slowly starts to bring you into the confined, restricted world of these characters. These people's lives are messy, contradictory, and a little bit sad. Mommy makes the case that these are people to be understood not to be pitied or cast aside.

A finely-etched melodrama from Canadian wunderkind Xavier Dolan, Mommy deftly chronicles the intoxicating yet loving relationship between a widow and her profane and violent ADHD son. The magic of Mommy is in traversing the fine line between the mother-son's love-hate relationship and exposing the emotional fragility of the dysfunctional pair who're inextricably woven together by their love for each other. Anchored by a pair of ferocious performances, Mommy pummels you with an emotional rollercoaster ride that teeters between hopeful levity and despair.

Life is what: what we are or what we show be?In Mommy, Dolan stands out as one of the great geniuses of the XXI century cinema.The film starts with the unconventional format 1: 1. Instagram format, squeezing the images and anguish, while they may be making a reference to own social network photos and your "perfect world" and makeup.Explores with great maturity, poetry and cruelty the relationship of a mother with her troubled son. Changes moments of poetry angry at times. At times, the film is commercial margarine in slow motion, in others it is the reality, naked.The clean performances of the actors and the meticulous soundtrack, sometimes blending two different styles of music, also in order to show two totally dissimilar worlds are other very strong points of the film.A great work of Dolan.

After five amazing feature-length films, I was under the impression that 25-year old writer/director Xavier Dolan would eventually run out of ways to impress and thrill me -- tuns out, he hasn't! Mommy is an unfiltered, unflinching, tight, suffocating masterpiece that's leaps and bounds ahead of any other film I've seen this year and yeah, DOLAN IS 25. this film tackles issues of suicide, loneliness, depression, and anxiety with such maturity that I sat there, shocked and leaping with joy inside.
It's powerful, mind blowing, shocking and perfect movie about people who are not perfect. But are you perfect? It brings to doubt everyone who watches Mommy.

best movie of 2014 foreign or otherwise

Dolan prend de la hauteur et signe son drame le plus abouti mais aussi le plus ambitieux. Si l'on reste dans les personnages a la marge, le sujet pousse le cineaste a prendre de la distance avec ses reperes habituels, a se faire plus observateur et ainsi a liberer sa capacite a saisir les instants d'emotion, ici moins arranges. Rarement la fatalite (et le bonheur fugace) n'a autant habite un film, au point d'en ecraser les plans. Le procede de recadrage est d'ailleurs presque superflu, les situations �tant suffisamment explicites et les acteurs justes dans leurs roles.

Dynamic is the word to describe why this works when it does. The emotional highs clash with the lows beautifully. Sometimes it's hard to breathe while watching. It's like a merging of Moodysson's talkative naturalism, Andrea Arnold's brash sensuality, and Almodovar's sentimentality. But that Almodovar factor is where it disconnected me in its story. The wings fall off when it flies too close to the sun. Perhaps even toning down the musical score would've helped (but not the amazing soundtrack)

Poderosamente bella y dolorosa. Mommy es un desaf�o sensorial, una pel�cula claustrof�bica que a veces, solamente a veces da un respiro y con ello, una enga�osa sensaci�n de esperanza, de paciencia. Una obra mayor sobre el amor y la ira. Deja una triste sensaci�n de abandono.

So I really had to wait so I could digest this film and be the most objective possible, and I fought to find the right words. The truth is, I loved it, I loved every single frame of it. There are so few movies that have made me feel the way that Dolan makes me feel with this, the editing, the direction, the acting and the photography are all master pieces by its own and together. The way the director plays with the layers of emotions of his viewers is really unbelievable and kind of mysterious and stunning. Dolan takes all the resources of cinema (! and He Really does!) to take his viewer through a shocking catharsis where not even the most insensitive human being can't get away of.

Nerve wrecking, family drama porn. Quite a bit contrived a gimmicky, it could have gotten stale fairly quickly if not for the tight editing and a cast which literally carried this movie on their broad shoulders. Almost shed a tear.

Many describe this Canadian film as an emotional horror show, and make no mistake, Mommy will leave you shaken. Writer-director Xavier Dolan debuted six years ago with I Killed My Mother and Oedipal issues are still on the menu in Mommy, in which a 15-year-old, omnisexual, possible bi-polar boy named Steve (Antoine Olivier Pilon) is more than his widowed mother, Diana 'Die' Despres (Anne Dorval) can handle.A new law taking effect in Quebec will allow for a parent to institutionalize a child without a court procedure, which gets Die to thinking. She's only about 50, and her tight pants and tall heels suggest she's not ready for retiring from life anytime soon. The trouble is that blond, blue-eyed Steve is very charming when not setting things on fire or threatening people with violence. Die seeks help from her neighbor (Suzanne Clement) a delicate looking teacher who only thinks she can contain Steve.One thing about Mommy: Even when Dolan hits you over the head with his themes, he puts on a show that burns in the memory with images that are unforgettable. Pilon is firing on all cylinders, but it's the tour de force from Dorval that transcends language and cultural barriers. Hers is a performance that dares you not to watch.

+Nothing annoys me more than walking out of a movie annoyed at the director and screenwriter and here I am, three hours later, still annoyed at the director and screenwriter of "Mommy", both being Xavier Dolan who also edited it.The basic story is interesting in that it deals with a mother whose son has been kicked out of a juvenile facility after causing a fire burning 75% of another boy's skin. The mother, Diane, nicknames Die and played by Anne Dorval, has been a widow for 3 years and the son, Steve, played by Antoine Olivier Pilon, hasn't accepted his father's death and had been previously diagnosed with ADD and/or possibly also being bi-polar. They are both capable of moods swinging form high highs to low lows. One moment he can be choking her and the next moment kissing her on the lips while she can be as tender with him as any mother can be and in the next moment bashing him over the head with a framed picture.Both the mother and son lean on their neighbor across the street who lives there with her boyfriend? Husband? And their young daughter. She, Kyla, played by Suzanne Clement, had been a high school teacher but due to something--a nervous breakdown?--has stopped teaching and she can barely talk in full sentences and stutters horribly except around the mother and son.Both mother and son are foul mouth speakers along with being flirtatious whenever the opportunity arises or, sometimes, instigating sexual innuendos. The language, in some instances, is definitely R rated.It is a good straight told story of a subject that isn't often a theme for movies, mainly in the first half but then the director/screenwriter/editor enters the picture. I want to excuse him because he is 25 years old but this is his fifth picture so he should know better. The film is mostly in a 1 to 1 ratio so most of the time you feel as if you are looking at it on a large cell phone. The screen is widen a few times but only effective and noticeable the first time. There are one too many blurry collages not too mention choppy editing that I guess is suppose to be 'artistic'. Also the screenwriter leaves way too many questions unanswered that are an important part of the story.Anne Dorval, Suzanne Clement and Antoine Olivier Pilon give excellent performances, especially the latter who has to handle showing all sides of a teenager with mental illness that changes him constantly.Aside from running far too long--two hours and 20 minutes--I felt frustration at how Dolan was taking a good story line and getting excessive with the camera. I found myself going from being interested to being bored and back and forth all during the movie and, finally, leaving annoyed.

Cuando la pel�cula termina con un "feet don't fail me now, take me to the finish line" un servidor ya est� en el borde de la butaca y no puede ser m�s feliz. Mommy es una pel�cula extravagante, obscura, amorosa, fabulosa, drogadicta. Te enamora, me enamor� totalmente. Con un tr�o (Dorval, Cl�ment, Pilon) que no puede estar mejor, de las mejores actuaciones del a�o totalmente, la fuerza de la imagen de una madre perdedora y de un hijo que est� en el caos. La vecina ser� ese pegamento que necesita y merece esta peque�a familia canadiense. La fotograf�a es una belleza, con tonalidades rojizas. El elemento del aspecto de la pel�cula se me hace muy acertado y esa manera en como este se agranda cuando vemos a la familia en sus momentos m�s felices. El soundtrack es fabuloso, y escuchar a Oasis y a Lana del Rey de fondo no es fortuito es maravilloso. De lo mejor del a�o. Gracias Dolan, gracias.

An emotional experience that I haven't had at the movies in quite a while. This is a film of intense beauty and incredibly dimensional characters. Mommy envelops you in the world of its characters and depicts the power of human connection like no other film I can remember.Xavier Dolan films Mommy in a 1:1 aspect ratio, which you've likely never seen before. It seems that this would be jarring, but not as much as you'd think, and works extremely well, in fact. Cutting off the wideness allows the characters to accompany larger portions of the frame, their bodies and heads are unobstructed by their surroundings. This is a film about deep human connection between a mother and her ADHD son, and they later welcome a neighbor into this world. It really is a whole other world that these characters occupy. One that's sometimes like a fantasy, or an escape, but one that's full of love. The square frame boxes us into their world.Watching these characters thrive in their world is a wonderful thing to see. The acting in this film is astonishing. The connection between the mother and son would not be so affective without the performances of Anne Dorval and Steve O'Connor Despr�s. These actors create strange, four-dimensional characters whose remarkable chemistry makes you feel like they've experienced the world together. Their connection is its own language. From far away they might look unstable and strange, but from up close we can see that no relationship is more loving or beautiful. Also great is Suzanne Cl�ment as the neighbor who finds herself becoming an unexpected part of this family. Dolan uses music in a unique way, with pop songs representing these characters lives. This is not Dolan putting in his iPod, as it might first seem, but is instead what the characters would play. Other noticeable stylistic choices are his use of slow motion and montage. These are used to capture the moments, or the essence of the moments of the characters, which is what Dolan is all about.The relationship between mother and son is important for the plot, and the film certainly tributes it, but the emotional power of the bond can be applied to any relationship. Dolan's film is like an homage to isolated human connection and spirit, but it's also tragic how this connection struggles to work with the real world.Although the aspect ratio and artistic style might lead some to think that this movie is not accessible, the storytelling is plenty decipherable. Anybody can enjoy this movie. It doesn't matter what films you like, or what you think you like, this film is driven emotionally, and everyone has emotions, so everyone can enjoy, and I think everyone will. I can't recommend this movie enough. You'd be doing yourself a tremendous favor to see it wherever you can, I guarantee you. It's the most exhilarating, unforgettable, filmgoing experience to surface from 2014.

Chaotic, difficult movie to watch or enjoy. If you want to watch a very dysfunctional relationship between a boy that is not only ADHD, but also out of control most of the movie, and a mom that has issues also, this is your movie. Lots of the F word to boot!!

Xavier Dolan's latest film is a thematic return to the material of "I Killed My Mother", only this film gives equal resonance to both the mother and child. A furious and loud film, Dolan also has a sense for the tender to make Mommy heartbreaking as well, and finds sublime chemistry in his trio of actors. The movie can often encroach on maudlin in it's more indulgent scenes (the soundtrack of 90's songs is admittedly quite bad) and Mommy's tone can be erratic, but it works overall, and houses some fairly innovative filmmaking. Filmed in a 1.1 ratio, it's unclear if this filming degree is truly necessary for the film, but it does allow for great close-up shots that show the emotional aspects of the characters. The most polished film from the Qu�becois auteur yet, even if it's a bit tonally uneven to be his best.

This is the second film I've seen by Dolan after Laurence anyways and I was less impressed because there were plot holes concerning all the lead characters. There were characters whose existence was meaningless and overall the film was too long
This is a horror show like you have never seen. Not for everyone, but fully deserving of all the acclaim it is getting.

MOMMY is so wonderful, insightful, energizing, and scary, that I truly cannot imagine a better film coming out in 2015. I loved everything about this latest from Xavier Dolan. Once again I am thrilled to celebrate a filmmaker who really captures who we are today. This film has the pulse and sensibility of 2015 without trying desperately in any way to be hip or cool. In fact, the film ain't hip it all. It just is TODAY! MOMMY blew me away.
Con Madre ..... la Direcci�n las Actuaciones la Fotograf�a la M�sica, Todo esta Incre�ble

For the fifth time in five years, now 25 year old wunderkind Xavier Dolan delivers another cinematic masterpiece. "Mommy" is in many ways a companion piece to Dolan's directorial debut "J'ai tu� ma m�re," the semiautobiographical tale of the then teenaged actor-turned-director's difficult relationship with his mother. The mother is still played by Anne Dorval. Whereas "J'ai tu� ma m�re" had a note of immature vengeance in it, "Mommy" is much more compassionate, nuanced and open to a point that makes it a bit difficult but ultimately rewarding to penetrate. The point of view is the mother's this time around.The film is set in a fictional Canada where parents are allowed to hand their children directly and completely over to state care citing financial reasons or threats of violence. Diane "Die" Despr�s (Dorval, explosively alive), a middle aged widower has to contemplate the possibility when her teenaged son Steve (Antoine-Olivier Pilon) is thrown out of a facility for troubled youth. Die is broke, doesn't feel confident in her ability to raise her erratic, often dangerously violent son. She drinks and is volatile herself. Now she has to assume direct responsibility of Steve's actions again.For me, Dolan is the most interesting director working today. I'm so glad he's been so prolific, because I anticipate every one of his films more than any others. In the beginning of this, his so-far greatest film festival success, I began to worry. The realistically shot scenes of Die and Steve building a life together were good, but they didn't completely enchant me the way I've come to expect from Dolan. Also, this is the director's most direct attempt at comedy, a difficult genre for me and again a good but not phenomenal effort during the first act. Was Dolan letting me down, or just my overgrown expectations of apotheosis?Throughout most the film I was unsure if "Mommy" was Dolan-phenomenal, just normal-phenomenal or just good. The director excels in depicting conflict and melodrama in ways that most filmmakers would turn off-putting or annoying. This film is at times off-putting and very annoying. Both Die and especially Steve are very difficult to like. The script is so daringly unpredictable it begins to border on incongruous. But it all grows, and after contemplating the film as a whole I was completely sold. The characters feel completely flesh-and-blood real, the melodrama turns effectively allegoric and the tonal confusion rewards the viewer after being processed.The key ingredient in making "Mommy" a true masterpiece is Kyla, a woman who lives across the street from Die with her family. Kyla is a teacher who is recovering from a heavy stutter brought on by an unspecified breakdown and resurfaced shyness. Kyla is injected into the story just as the relationship between the protagonist mother and her son turns dangerously violent. She befriends the disastrous duo and balances the dynamic.Kyla is played by Suzanne Cl�ment who portrayed a similar teacher in "J'ai tu� ma m�re" and a vastly different character in Dolan's 2012 tour de force "Laurence Anyways". She shows her amazing range again in a role that defines the drama, offering a reflective surface to the otherwise numbingly fierce exchanges between Die and Steve. In the end Steve and Die may be the main characters, but Kyla is our companion as viewers, the silent focus point that brings the emotional cacophony together into something tangible.As always, cinematography and music are Xavier Dolan's allies even more than they are in an average film. This time, the soundtrack is actually quite bad for my taste; emotional pop from the 90's mainly, but the director makes it work. In a Dolan scene, even Celine Dion has an impact. Trust me. The cinematography gets more experimental as the film progresses, forming yet again a unique, exceptionally beautiful language that takes us within the characters. Some frames are so tenderly beautiful they make you want to cry.What "Mommy" is most notably successful in is the melancholy, deeply felt presentation of youth, mostly from a parent's perspective. Pilon's Steve is dangerously volatile and dangerously fragile, explosive, infuriating, but so very real. I remember being told as a kid by some relatives that teen years were hazardous, that people often messed up everything during that period of flux. I was dead afraid of my own back then. I thankfully never got or wanted into any trouble, but now I'm glad this film didn't exist when I was that timid child afraid of growing up. If I had seen "Mommy" then, I wouldn't have been just afraid, I would have been in panic.
"A marathon for amazing performance"
Destruktivt och livsbejakande. K�nslom�ssig berg- och dalbana. Intensivt v�lspelat drama som l�mnar en omtumlad. Dolans b�sta hittills.
Great Intense and real family drama

Xavier Dolan is a brilliant director. The 1:1 aspect ratio he chose allow the viewer to be more connected to the characters. They are white suburbian underachievers, they speak quebecquois patois, a mix of french and english expressions and insults. Those people are pretty intense but we get attached to them. This movie explores social and psychological issue with at its core a very strong mother-son relationship. It's very emotionnal but also interesting and original. The music plays a role of paramount importance. Some scenes are beautiful, rare moments of joy and happiness, where Dolan's virtuoso makes the camera fly around and shoot in slow motion.
A harsh, compelling and moving drama movie. Mommy is the best Xavier Dolan work to date.
A heartbreaking drama spiced up with a little joie de vivre, Mommy is the living proof that Xavier Dolan has become a mature director.

Wunderkind Dolan (25 years old & this is his fifth movie) builds wave after wave of intensity in this shattering character study of damaged families trying their best to fit into a society which just seems impossible to navigate. Anne Dorval is amazing as the fierce and wacky Mommy who improvises her parenting and providing skills as a recent widow without much going for her but looks and love. Pilon is amazing as the explosive adolescent Steve, a singular creation for such a young actor. Dolan's sense of pacing, framing, scoring and use of music, and his work with actors is pretty remarkable. This is a career to watch.
A stunning achievement by a 25 year old director, Mommy is a powerful work that provides everything from dark comedy to light, fear, sadness, and love. It is not a movie to be missed.
encantador, hipnotizante, fascinante...o 'enfant terrible' do cinema volta a nos presentear e agora com seu melhor filme at� a data.

A beautiful story about a mom who wants the best for her son and a boy who can't always control himself but loves with mom above all. This story shows us that love is not always enough to save someone but it's always important to have hope. With spectacular performances from the cast, a powerful script, a touching soundtrack and a beautiful editing, Xavier Dolan proves one more time that he's here to surprise us with every single film he does.
meus amigos, que filme.

It's a very intense movie, full of emotional implication from both Dolan and the characters. However, the drive of the storyline seems to lack pace and becomes dead-alive. At times there are peaks where the film manages to stimulate the pulse of the narrative, but it seems to have trouble maintaining that trait. Dolan has failed to structure a solid film which could've been a potential masterpiece, it's time for him to consider polishing his storytelling technique to render his creative capacity into a more compelling talent. A few touch ups in the script would've also boosted up the quality, however the use of visual techniques and musical montages resinates very adequately and raises the mood thoroughly of the movie. I, however, always fill sufficed when analyzing Dolan's movies, as they possess a very personal bond with their director. Ultimately I would recommend the film, but a better experience is assured if costumers wait until it's released on demand and they can enjoy it home where they can take rests and wear off the tediousness that is sometimes build up.

A decent but irregular effort that feels too long for the kind of story that it wants to tell and not really well polished as a whole, while its unusual aspect ratio of 1:1 may be interesting, especially as a basis for the most beautiful scene of the film, but also starts to bother after some time.

Tense. I walked home after watching this with almost a limp after digging my toes into one of my shoes. You of course see where this boy gets a lot of his craziness, more as the film progresses. The manic episodes couldn't be more riviting & like so many life choices, you can see the truthfulness of the reactions at the same time that you witness the unstable fire.
Marvel at how powerful some scenes can be.
Fake fake fake... fake Canadian "law", fake feelings, faking actors, absurd situation. Total waste of time.

An already accomplished filmmaker at only 25, Dolan shows in this movie the extent of his talent when it comes to representing empathy and feelings. Also, he loves people who struggle and are at-a-loss to understand what's happening to them but who still fight to make something out of their lives. He has all of this with the scenario and afterwards, it's just showing off his talent in a great fashion. The way he uses this particular square screen (and more precisely the changes from square to regular) give way to two of the most extraordinary scenes ever made.
Mommy could have been a lot shorter - true it is a movie with many complex life issues but too much vulgarity/cursing . All main actors were good but Xavier was great . Overall Acceptable.

Presentada en SANFIC10, Mommy es una obra maestra. Dolan es uno de los mejores directores del mundo a sus apenas 25 a�os. Con un historia parecida a J'ai tue? ma me?re, vemos esta vez a Steve, un ni�o con ataques de violencia que debe reintegrarse a la vida con su madre. Kyla, su vecina, ser� su ayuda y estabilidad. Emotiva como pocas pel�culas que haya visto, puede volverse un poco larga, pero es algo que todos debiesen ver.

Pondre un film aussi puissant que Mommy n'est pas une mince affaire et force est de constater que Xavier Dolan s'en sort parfaitement bien, gr�ce � des choix de mise en sc�ne bien pr�cis (que ce soit dans le cadre ou dans la musique parfaite en tout point), tout en ne c�dant jamais � l'appel du m�lodrame. Anne Dorval et Suzanne Cl�ment sont exceptionnelles, le rythme insuffl� � l'histoire est ad�quat et l'�quilibre entre fond et forme est extr�mement ma�tris�. Excellent.

This movie is brutal. Not in a violent way, but its raw emotion and close cinematography makes it seem like you're being injected right into a family's turbulent life. With arthouse style usage of music, combined with powerful performances, Mommy explores a parent's unconditional love in the most extreme ways, as well as exploring mental illness and other complex issues.

Xavier Dolan is a very talented young French Canadian flim maker - Canada's oscar entry for next years foreign language nonetheless - there's plenty of Gallic farce, there's also a lot of effing too (that's just going by the subtitles!) - on top of that love the visual tricks in the cinematography that make this a pleasure to watch, interspersed with the usual cleverly selected soundtrack, the characters are all pretty crazy - Mommy has a problem, her young tearaway son is a bit of a handful, she loves him to bits - but can she cope? Loved the faux ending - I really thought that was that! This is the fourth film of Dolan's I've watched, they all have great narratives and twists - never disappoints.
10/10 C'et un chef d'oeuvre. C'est une tornade. C'est de la pure �motion visc�rale. Il n'y a que du talent � l'�cran. Inoubliable.

I was really excited to see Mommy. The buzz around this film has been huge and I loved Xavier Dolan's last film. Well, Mommy is a near masterpiece that proves to be one of the greatest foreign language films I've ever seen.The story follows a single mother who must raise her very troubled teenage son, who finds hope when their neighbour comes into her life. The story in this movie is detailed and terrific. It begins fairly slowly, but it speeds up and never fails to interest. The characters are amazing, too. Each character is relatable and perfectly realized. There are only about three important characters, but that makes allows the movie to expand on their personalities. Even with a massive runtime of 2 and a half hours, the movie never gets too slow and you barely feel the length.The acting in this movie is some of the best of the year. Anne Dorval gives an amazing and Oscar worthy performance. Antoine-Olivier Pilon gives a brilliant performance as a teenager with severe ADHD. Suzanne Cl�ment also gives an excellent performance as a wonderful neighbour. I would love to see all three of these actors in more movies, because they were all fantastic!The directing in this film is just...wow. Xavier Dolan proves to be one of the most unique and brilliant directors working today, and this is only his second film! The way frames were used to effect the audience was just brilliant, and some scenes were visually gorgeous. I was constantly interested in the story and the characters throughout. The writing in this movie is also brilliant, with great uses of extreme profanity and some very touching moments. There is also a bit of comedy that hits pretty hard and balances out the heart-wrenching moments. My only small problem with the movie is that it feels like a bunch of short films bound together. Some plot elements were dropped and completely forgotten at some points. Other than that, though, this movie was nearly perfect.Overall, Mommy is a must-see for all film lovers alike! It has brilliant performances, a wonderful story and terrific direction! Please, run out and see this ASAP!RATING: 9.75/10
Xavier is brilliant and this film is gonna win Oscar

Een tamelijk zelfzuchtig psycho drama dat wellicht een mooie vondst heeft in zijn brute realistische verhaal, maar weet daarmee niet de onevenwichtigheid van zijn personages onder bedwang te houden. Mommy is zeker geen slechte film, maar zal wel een verdeeld publiek krijgen over zijn onorthodoxe manier van filmmaken.

Filed by strong performances from it's lead cast and a brilliant direction by Xavier Dolan, Mommy is an original piece of filmaking, and be it somewhat a little too long, still is worth the price of admission just for the fantastic performances.
Xavier Dolan's 'Mommy' is a bittersweet, heart-warming-and-breaking Masterpiece. A definite 'Must See'! #XavierDolan #Mommy

Mommy is an emotional maelstrom that will transport you from the begining till the end by its beauty, its paradoxes, its sincerity, its richness. Rarely I have the chance to feel the kind of emotions I felt by watching Mommy. A modern masterpiece you will remember for a long time. A must!

this movie is so powerful, moving and true. Nowhere pretencious, the performances are simply amazing. Dolan's best achievement yet. Run to see it!

Canada's entry for Best Foreign Language Film at the 87th Academy Awards, "Mommy" is Xavier Dolan's best work to date. It's a powerfully moving film with smothering performances and Dolan's trademark style. It will punch you in the gut, seemingly for the fun of it, then show you the valid intention of that punch that will leave you in somber gratitude. Good luck at this year's Oscars, "Mommy." I have very high hopes for you.

xavier dolan has arrived. oh my god was this film magnificent. dolan has really come into his own as a filmmaker and this film is a testament to all the work he's done in his astoundingly young career. he has reached an equilibrium both in his visual style and as a storyteller, creating a film that is equal parts human, humorous, devastating and ethereal in its unconventional aesthetics. this film is proof that even the simplest stories, in the hands of a master, can be extraordinary.

This film is gritty, moving and emotionally draining. The majority of the film is in the tone of shouting which is like an onslaught that it's meant to be. Performances are great and believable. It's rather a depressing movie as it deals with difficult themes. It doesn't divert into cliche which is good. Also, the music choices are great and suit the film really well.
Best film I've seen this year so far.
